articles.description:
Jay Hou, Software Engineer, TrustFabric (transparency.dev)¬†




Pixel Binary Transparency
With Android powering billions of devices, we‚Äôve long put security first. There‚Äôs the more visible security features you might interact with regularly, like spam and phishing protection, as well as less obvious integrated security features, like daily scans for malware. For example, Android Verified Boot strives to ensure all executed code comes from a trusted source, rather than from an attacker or corruption. And with attacks on software and mobile devices constantly evolving, we‚Äôre continually strengthening these features and adding transparency into how Google protects users. This blog post peeks under the hood of Pixel Binary Transparency, a recent addition to Pixel security that puts you in cont‚Ä¶
articles.title: Pixel Binary Transparency: verifiable security for Pixel devices

articles.description:
Maddie Stone, Security Researcher, Threat Analysis Group (TAG)


This is Google‚Äôs fourth annual year-in-review of 0-days exploited in-the-wild [2021, 2020, 2019] and builds off of the mid-year 2022 review. The goal of this report is not to detail each individual exploit, but instead to analyze the exploits from the year as a whole, looking for trends, gaps, lessons learned, and successes.¬†
Executive Summary
41 in-the-wild 0-days were detected and disclosed in 2022, the second-most ever recorded since we began tracking in mid-2014, but down from the 69 detected in 2021.¬† Although a 40% drop might seem like a clear-cut win for improving security, the reality is more complicated. Some of our key takeaways from 2022 include:





N-days function like 0-days on Android due to long patching time‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Ups and Downs of 0-days: A Year in Review of 0-days Exploited In-the-Wild in 2022

articles.description:
Julie Qiu, Go Security & Reliability and Jonathan Metzman, Google Open Source Security Team


Previously in our Supply chain security for Go series, we covered dependency and vulnerability management tools and how Go ensures package integrity and availability as part of the commitment to countering the rise in supply chain attacks in recent years.¬†
In this final installment, we‚Äôll discuss how ‚Äúshift left‚Äù security can help make sure you have the security information you need, when you need it, to avoid unwelcome surprises.¬†
Shifting left

The software development life cycle (SDLC) refers to the series of steps that a software project goes through, from planning all the way through operation. It‚Äôs a cycle because once code has been released, the process continues and repeats through actions‚Ä¶
articles.title: Supply chain security for Go, Part 3: Shifting left

articles.description:
Posted by Alex Gough, Chrome Security Team

Security Review in Chrome
feature flag and must pass a Launch Review before turning it on. Teams think about security early-on and coordinate with the security team. Teams are responsible for the safety of their features and ensuring that the security team is able to say ‚Äòyes‚Äô to its security review.


Security review focuses on the design of a proposed feature, not its details and is distinct from code review. Chrome changes need approval from engineers familiar with the code being changed but not necessarily from security experts. It is not practical for security engineers to scrutinize every change. Instead we focus on the feature‚Äôs architecture, and how it might affect people using Chrome.


Reviewers function best in an open and supportive e‚Ä¶
articles.title: A look at Chrome‚Äôs security review culture

articles.description:
Posted by Giles Hogben, Privacy Engineering Director


Most modern consumer messaging platforms (including Google Messages) support end-to-end encryption, but users today are limited to communicating with contacts who use the same platform. This is why Google is strongly supportive of regulatory efforts that require interoperability for large end-to-end messaging platforms.


For interoperability to succeed in practice, however, regulations must be combined with open, industry-vetted, standards, particularly in the area of privacy, security, and end-to-end encryption. Without robust standardization, the result will be a spaghetti of ad hoc middleware that could lower security standards to cater for the lowest common denominator and raise implementation costs, particularly for smaller providers. Lack of standardization would also make advanced features such as end-to-end encrypted group messaging impossible in practice ‚Äì group messages would have to be encrypted and delivered multiple times to cater for every different protocol.


With the recent publication of the IETF‚Äôs Message Layer Security (MLS) specification RFC 9420, messaging users can look forward to this reality. For the first time, MLS enables practical interoperability across services and platforms, scaling to groups of thousands of multi-device users. It is also flexible enough to allow providers to  address emerging threats to user privacy and security, such as quantum computing.  


By ensuring a uniformly high security and privacy bar that users can trust, MLS will unleash a huge field of new opportunities for the users and developers of  interoperable messaging services that adopt it. This is why we intend to build MLS into Google Messages and support its wide deployment across the industry by open sourcing our implementation in the Android codebase.
articles.title: An important step towards secure and interoperable messaging

articles.description:
This week Adam is joined by Abi Noda, founder and CEO of DX to talk about DX AKA DevEx (or the long-form Developer Experience). Since the dawn of software development there has been this push to understand what makes software teams efficient, but more importantly what does it take to understand developer productivity? That‚Äôs what Abi has been focused on for the better part of the last 8 years of his career. He started a company called Pull Panda that was acquired by GitHub, spent a few years there on this problem before going out on his own to start DX which helps startups to the fortune 500 companies gather real insights that leads to real improvement.

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Our Frontend Feud game show series forces me to survey JS Party listeners frequently to get their thoughts on software, development, life, and software development life.
Each question has to be accompanied by an <input type=text> because providing choices ruins the entire point of the game. So, before we play I compile all the answers in an SQLite database, group similar responses, and put the most popular ones on the game board.
That ‚Äúgrouping similar responses‚Äù step is the hardest part and can be somewhat controversial during the games. I‚Äôve gotten better over the years at crafting the questions to constrain the responses.
For example, instead of asking: ‚ÄúHow do you feel about GitHub Copilot?‚Äù
We ask: ‚ÄúIn one word, how does GitHub Copilot make you feel?‚Äù
"Anxious" works better in a `GROU‚Ä¶
articles.title: Things we always remind ourselves while coding

There‚Äôs so much talk (and hype) these days about vector databases. We thought it would be timely and practical to have someone on the show that has been hands on with the various options and actually tried to build applications leveraging vector search. Prashanth Rao is a real practitioner that has spent and huge amount of time exploring the expanding set of vector database offerings. After introducing vector database and giving us a mental model of how they fit in with other datastores, Prashanth digs into the trade offs as related to indices, hosting options, embedding vs. query optimization, and more.

articles.description:
This week we‚Äôre talking about type checking with Jake Zimmerman. Jake is one of the leads at Stripe working on Sorbet ‚Äî an open source project that does Type checking in Ruby and runs over Stripe‚Äôs entire Ruby codebase. As of May of 2022 Stripe‚Äôs codebase was over 15 million lines of code spread across 150,000 files. If you think you have a bigger Ruby codebase, Jake is down to go byte-for-byte to see who wins. Jake shares tons of wisdom and more importantly he shares why he thinks types will win in the end.
Leave us a comment
Changelog++ members get a bonus 4 minutes at the end of this episode and zero ads. Join today!
Sponsors:

  
Sentry ‚Äì¬†Code-level APM built for developers! Stay ahead of latency issues and trace every slow transaction to a poor-performing API call or database query. S‚Ä¶
articles.title: Changelog Interviews 548: Types will win in the end

articles.description:
Chris sat down with Varun Mohan and Anshul Ramachandran, CEO / Cofounder and Lead of Enterprise and Partnership at Codeium, respectively. They discussed how to streamline and enable modern development in generative AI and large language models (LLMs).  Their new tool, Codeium, was born out of the insights they gleaned from their work in GPU software and solutions development, particularly with respect to generative AI, large language models, and supporting infrastructure.  Codeium is a free AI-powered toolkit for developers, with in-house models and infrastructure - not another API wrapper.
Leave us a comment

articles.title: Practical AI 231: A developer's toolkit for SOTA AI

articles.description:
Darcy Clarke, former GitHub Staff Engineering Manager and founder of vlt, joins us to discuss a major bug in the npm ecosystem that he recently disclosed. We cover the bug‚Äôs timeline, nuances, and impact, all while setting some important context on npm packages, clients, and registries. Tune in to learn how to protect your codebase and gain a deeper understanding of this crucial part of the JavaScript ecosystem.

articles.author: Daniel Stenberg
articles.description: The curl option ‚Äìwrite-out is one of my personal favorites and offers users an excitingly powerful way to output information from a transfer. Over time, it has been extended to provide more and more features. It was for example not that long ago we added the ability to output the content of specific headers with ‚Ä¶ Continue reading curl write-out to files ‚Üí
articles.title: curl write-out to files

articles.author: Daniel Stenberg
articles.description: If you are anything like me, you appreciate solving your every day simple tasks directly from the command line. Creating crafty single shot command lines or a small shell script to solve that special task you figured out you needed and makes your day go a little smoother. A fellow command line cowboy. Video presentation ‚Ä¶ Continue reading introducing curl command line variables ‚Üí
articles.title: introducing curl command line variables

articles.author: Daniel Stenberg
articles.description: Welcome. Due to some annoying regressions in the previous release we think we owned it to everyone to do a quick patch follow-up. Download curl 8.2.1 from https://curl.se. Release presentation Numbers the 221st release0 changes7 days (total: 9,259)27 bug-fixes (total: 9,194)37 commits (total: 30,646)0 new public libcurl function (total: 91)0 new curl_easy_setopt() option (total: 303)0 ‚Ä¶ Continue reading curl 8.2.1 ‚Üí

articles.author: Daniel Stenberg
articles.description: Welcome to another curl release. You know how this dance goes‚Ä¶ Numbers the 220th release5 changes50 days (total: 9,252)122 bug-fixes (total: 9,167)177 commits (total: 30,606)0 new public libcurl function (total: 91)1 new curl_easy_setopt() option (total: 303)4 new curl command line option (total: 255)55 contributors, 34 new (total: 2,922)35 authors, 20 new (total: 1,170)1 security fixes ‚Ä¶ Continue reading curl 8.2.0 ‚Üí

sources.title: Mozilla Hacks ‚Äì the Web developer blog

articles.author: Stephen Hood
articles.description:
Artificial intelligence may well prove one of the most impactful and disruptive technologies to come along in years. We want to understand, support, and contribute to these efforts because we believe that they offer one of the best ways to help ensure that the AI systems that emerge are truly trustworthy. With this in mind, a small team within Mozilla‚Äôs innovation group recently undertook a hackathon at our headquarters in San Francisco. Our objective: build a Mozilla internal chatbot prototype.
The post So you want to build your own open source chatbot‚Ä¶ appeared first on Mozilla Hacks - the Web developer blog.
articles.title: So you want to build your own open source chatbot‚Ä¶

articles.author: Jon Peck
articles.description: In the world of software development, collaboration can make the difference between a brittle last-minute release and a reliable, maintainable, pain-free project. Whether you‚Äôve been coding for a day or a decade, your colleagues are there to help strengthen your work. But they can only help if you‚Äôve given them the tools to do so.
articles.title: A checklist and guide to get your repository collaboration-ready

articles.author: Ryan J. Salva
articles.description: Today, we‚Äôre announcing a private beta of GitHub Copilot with code referencing that includes a filter to detect code suggestions matching public code on GitHub.
articles.title: Introducing code referencing for GitHub Copilot

articles.author: David Losert
articles.description: Learn how you can structure your enterprise to get the most value out of GitHub and provide the best experience for your developers!
articles.title: Best practices for organizations and teams using GitHub Enterprise Cloud

articles.author: MV Karan
articles.description: Learn about how we build containerized services that power microservices on the GitHub.com platform and many internal tools.
articles.title: How we build containerized services at GitHub using GitHub

articles.author: Shuyin Zhao
articles.description: We're thrilled to announce two major updates to GitHub Copilot code Completion's capabilities that will help developers work even more efficiently and effectively.
articles.title: Smarter, more efficient coding: GitHub Copilot goes beyond Codex with improved AI model

articles.author: Peter St√∂ckli
articles.description: This blog post describes two security vulnerabilities in Decidim, a digital platform for citizen participation. Both vulnerabilities were addressed by the Decidim team with corresponding update releases for the supported versions in May 2023.
articles.title: Closing vulnerabilities in Decidim, a Ruby-based citizen participation platform

articles.author: Matt Cooper
articles.description: GitHub switched to performing merges and rebases using merge-ort. Come behind the scenes to see why and how we made this change.
articles.title: Scaling merge-ort across GitHub

articles.author: Peter Cihon
articles.description: Sharing our coalition paper to inform the final negotiation of the EU AI Act.
articles.title: How to get AI regulation right for open source

articles.author: Lee Reilly
articles.description: Game Bytes is our monthly series taking a peek at the world of gamedev on GitHub‚Äîfeaturing game engine updates, game jam details, open source games, mods, maps, and more. Game on!
articles.title: Game Bytes ¬∑ July 2023

articles.author: Kedasha Kerr
articles.description: In this step-by-step tutorial, you will learn how to use GitHub Copilot to build an application with OpenAI‚Äôs gpt-3.5-turbo model.
articles.title: How to build a GPT-3 App with Nextjs, React, and GitHub Copilot

articles.author: Shelley McKinley
articles.description: We‚Äôre launching the GitHub Copilot Trust Center to provide transparency about how GitHub Copilot works and help organizations innovate responsibly with generative AI.
articles.title: How to responsibly adopt GitHub Copilot with the GitHub Copilot Trust Center

articles.author: Patrick Knight
articles.description: Repository rules provide an easy, flexible way to define branch protections and ensure consistency in code across repositories.
articles.title: GitHub Repository Rules are now generally available

articles.author: Mario Rodriguez
articles.description: All GitHub Copilot for Business users now have access to a limited GitHub Copilot Chat beta, bringing the power of conversational coding right to the IDE.
articles.title: GitHub Copilot Chat beta now available for every organization

articles.author: Amanda Swan
articles.description: As a design organization, we have the opportunity to make a significant impact on designing the platform for all developers. How does the emergence of creative AI impact our work? How can we achieve an inclusive experience for a spectrum of all abilities? What does designing for developer happiness look like?
articles.title: Exploring developer happiness, inclusion, and productivity at GitHub‚Äôs Design Conference

articles.author: Zack Koppert
articles.description: With the new Issue Metrics GitHub Action, you can now track and monitor important metrics related to issues, pull requests, and discussions, such as time to first response, time to close, and more!
articles.title: Metrics for issues, pull requests, and discussions

articles.author: Alexis Wales
articles.description: GitHub has identified a low-volume social engineering campaign that targets the personal accounts of employees of technology firms. No GitHub or npm systems were compromised in this campaign. We‚Äôre publishing this blog post as a warning for our customers to prevent exploitation by this threat actor.
articles.title: Security alert: social engineering campaign targets technology industry employees

articles.author: Albert Ziegler
articles.description: Prompt engineering is the art of communicating with a generative AI model. In this article, we‚Äôll cover how we approach prompt engineering at GitHub, and how you can use it to build your own LLM-based application.
articles.title: A developer‚Äôs guide to prompt engineering and LLMs

articles.author: Michelle Mannering
articles.description: It‚Äôs been a while since we‚Äôve published our Release Radar. You can blame IRL conferences coming back, getting influenza, and being struck down by the weather. But those are just me problems. While I‚Äôve been down or travelling, the community has been hard at work shipping new releases and new projects. So, we thought we‚Äôd [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Release Radar ¬∑ Spring 2023 Edition

articles.author: Martin Woodward
articles.description: Navigating the ebb and flow of programming paradigms‚Äìfrom the shifts in the JavaScript ecosystem and TypeScript's rise, to AI's role in advancing accessibility, and strategies for encouraging non-code contributions‚Äìtune in to the latest episode of The ReadME Podcast for more.
articles.title: (De)coding conventions

articles.author: Chris Reddington
articles.description: Thanks to DevOps, cloud computing and other industry trends, many organizations are shifting from a product mindset to a service mindset. Here‚Äôs how you can implement a service-led strategy.
articles.title: Moving from a product to a service mindset

articles.author: Jakub Oleksy
articles.description: In June, we experienced two incidents that resulted in degraded performance across GitHub services.¬† June 7 16:11 UTC (lasting 2 hours 28 minutes) On June 7 at 16:11 UTC, GitHub started experiencing increasing delays in an internal job queue used to process Git pushes. Our monitoring systems alerted our first responders after 19 minutes. During [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: GitHub Availability Report: June 2023

articles.author: Mike Linksvayer
articles.description: Have your say to protect open source in the EU.
articles.title: No cyber resilience without open source sustainability

articles.author: Dustin Yin
articles.description: Supercharge pull request merges on your busiest branches by enabling your team to queue.
articles.title: GitHub merge queue is generally available

articles.author: Hirsch Singhal
articles.description: Passkeys are now available in public beta. Opting in lets you upgrade security keys to passkeys, and use those in place of both your password and your 2FA method.
articles.title: Introducing passwordless authentication on GitHub.com

articles.author: Ariel Deitcher
articles.description: Level up your use of GitHub Projects on the command line and in GitHub Actions with the new project CLI command.
articles.title: GitHub CLI project command is now generally available!

articles.author: Philip Holleran
articles.description: Reduce developer and auditor friction involved in demonstrating compliance and maintaining end-to-end traceability by focusing your efforts around the pull request.
articles.title: Demonstrating end-to-end traceability with pull requests

articles.description:
Tech team thanks Rich Hickey for leadership as he retires from his position at Nu.¬†
The post Clojure‚Äôs journey at Nubank: a look into the future appeared first on Building Nubank.
articles.title: Clojure‚Äôs journey at Nubank: a look into the future

Contextual recommendations for better financial outcomes: how this feature optimizes your choices.

articles.title: Smarter banking: how intelligent suggestions in the Nubank app empower customers

articles.author: elizabeth@hackerone.com
articles.description:
‚ÄúAt Amazon, protecting our customers‚Äô information is our top priority. Part of those efforts includes our bug bounty program through HackerOne, which allows participating researchers to submit findings directly to the company. We work with researchers across the security industry that reach out about potential issues that may impact our customers, and we take steps to investigate and fix them. Events like H1-213 provide our security teams with the unique opportunity to engage a diverse group of ethical, independent researchers.‚Äù
-	Travis Lee, Senior Manager, Offensive Security
articles.title: Amazon's Security Researcher Collaboration: Highlights from H1-213

articles.author: Elizabeth Raffa
articles.description:
"Cybersecurity is on everyone‚Äôs radar, but not everyone knows all the specific details to ensure protection. We know bad actors are constantly looking for cracks in our defenses and applications. That's why it's so important for us to work with ethical hackers. They know what vulnerabilities the bad actors are looking for, and they know how to find them before the bad guys can."
- Jillian Burner, CISO, Ohio Secretary of State
articles.title: Five Takeaways from Ohio Secretary of State's VDP Success Story

articles.author: Joe Coletta
articles.description: Compounding security debt from daily new releases creates serious challenges for security organizations ‚Äî especially considering the scarcity of skilled personnel. Point-in-time security measures and an overreliance on automation and AI create a false sense of security that often leaves the door open for attackers.
articles.title: Security Should Never Sleep: Adopting Continuous Testing for Evolving Threats

articles.author: Michiel Prins
articles.description: GAI capabilities will soon be table stakes for any software company as their customers will simply expect it. Those who do not take advantage of this technological evolution will decline into irrelevancy and be replaced by better and more productive alternatives. A world where Generative AI is ubiquitous will soon be here. What does that mean for security? We have two main predictions.
articles.title: Generative AI and Security: HackerOne's Predictions
